item.title: Plenary Panel
item.description: With Professor Christine Szymanski, Professor Sam Sheppard, Professor Brendan Wren, Dr Arnoud van Vliet. Day 3 Friday 10th September 2021. 16:00-17:30 (BST/UTC+1)
item.content:encoded:
Zoom link: TBA

Discord link: https://discord.gg/X7RNaUbczg

Session times

  • Day 3 Friday 10th September 2021. 16:00-17:30 (BST/UTC+1)

About this session

This year’s plenary session will be a discussion panel from four eminent experts in the field of Campylobacter. Expect a lively discussion on the broader trends - past, present and future - in Campylobacter research.

Panel members include:

  • Professor Christine Szymanski
  • Professor Sam Sheppard
  • Professor Brendan Wren
  • Dr Arnoud van Vliet

Professor Christine Szymanski

Dr. Szymanski has been exploring bacterial glycomics for more than two decades, working on food pathogens since the early 1990s, with a particular emphasis on Campylobacter jejuni. She combines her expertise in food safety and animal health with novel therapeutic diagnostic platforms developed during her postdoctoral fellowship at the Naval Medical Research Center vaccine program (1996-2000), the key findings while employed at the National Research Council of Canada (2000-2008), and the translational advances during her tenure as an Alberta Innovates Technology Futures Scholar at the University of Alberta (2008-2016). She was the first to demonstrate that bacteria are capable of N-glycosylating proteins and is now exploiting these systems to create glycoconjugate vaccines and oral therapeutics through recombinant expression in Escherichia coli. Dr. Szymanski was also the first to demonstrate that viruses specific for bacteria express proteins that can be used as novel therapeutics in addition to their recognized diagnostic value. These viruses (bacteriophages) are the most abundant biological entity on earth (1031) and are therefore a limitless resource for exploitation, especially in the area of glycomics.

The Szymanski laboratory uses multidisciplinary approaches to 1) characterize pathways responsible for generating bacterial glycoconjugates and 2) exploit viral recognition proteins that bind to these structures to develop novel platforms for agricultural and food safety applications. Our studies are now expanding to the analyses of carbohydrate metabolism and bacteriophage influence on the gut microbiome, and development of glycoconjugate vaccines against other pathogens.

Professor Sam Sheppard

Professor and director of Bioinformatics (Milner Centre for Evolution) at the University of Bath and Co-PI of MRC CLIMB (Cloud Infrastructure for Microbial Bioinformatics)–the UKs largest cloud-based system for the analysis of microbial genomes.

Research in my group centres on the use of genetics/genomics and phenotypic studies to address complex questions in the ecology, epidemiology and evolution of microbes. Our most recent interests focus upon comparative genome analyses to describe the core and flexible genome of pathogenic bacteria (Campylobacter, Staphylococcus, Helicobacter and Escherichia coli) and how this is related to population genetic structuring, the maintenance of species, and the evolution of host/niche adaptation and virulence.

Professor Brendan Wren

​​Brendan Wren’s research interests predominantly involve determining the genetic basis by which bacterial pathogens cause disease. His research group exploits a range of post genome research strategies to gain a comprehensive understanding of how these pathogens function, how they evolve and how they interact with their respective hosts. A core interest includes studying glycosylation and glycostructures and how this relates to the survival and virulence of bacterial pathogens. An application of this basic research is the development of Protein Glycan Coupling Technology and other glycobiotechnological innovations for the production of recombinant glycoproteins. This has been applied for the development of inexpensive glycoconjugate vaccines for human and veterinary use.

Dr Arnoud van Vliet

Arnoud graduated in 1991 from Utrecht University, The Netherlands, studying Medical Biology. He obtained his PhD in 1995 from the Veterinary Microbiology department of the Utrecht University, working on molecular characterisation and detection of the tick-borne ruminant pathogen Cowdria (Ehrlichia) ruminantium. For his postdoc, he moved to the Department of Genetics of the University of Leicester, UK, working on gene regulation and virulence of the zoonotic foodborne pathogen Campylobacter jejuni. He then obtained a personal fellowship in 1999 from the Dutch Organisation for Scientific Research (NWO) to work on metal metabolism, gene regulation in the human gastric pathogen Helicobacter pylori, first at the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, and subsequently as lecturer at the Erasmus MC-University Medical Center in Rotterdam. In 2007, he took up a position as Research Leader at the Institute of Food Research, Norwich, UK, where he has led a research group focusing on the foodborne pathogens Campylobacter and Listeria, combining microbiology, molecular biology, genomics and other ‘omics with bioinformatic technologies, to understand the processes allowing these bacteria to survive in the food chain and cause illness.

Arnoud had joined the Surrey Vet School as Senior Lecturer in Veterinary microbiology in October 2016.

item.title: Industry session - Day 3 (10th September 2021)
item.content:encoded:
Zoom link: TBA

Discord link: https://discord.gg/X7RNaUbczg

Session times

  • Day 3 Friday 10th September 2021. 13:00-14:00 (BST/UTC+1)

About this session

This session will involve a discussion with industry partners about their views on combating Campylobacter and the role research can play.

Panel members include:

  • Keith Warner, representing Avara
  • Dr Aaron Mckenna, representing Moy Park

About Avara

Avara leads the way in healthy, versatile and great tasting food. Avara Foods is one of the UK’s largest food businesses, supplying chicken and turkey to the nation’s most popular supermarkets and restaurants. We excel at what we do. You might not have heard of us but there’s a good chance you’ve enjoyed our products. We are one of the UK’s biggest food businesses, supplying great tasting chicken and turkey to some of the biggest supermarkets and restaurants in the country.We may only have been formed in 2018, but we have a history and heritage that dates back to the early 1960’s. Formed in a joint venture between Cargill’s UK fresh poultry business and Faccenda, we’ve been able to build on the experience and expertise gained from five decades industry service. We are a new, ambitious company with a forward-thinking mindset. You’ll find our dedicated teams all over the UK and whether it be our agricultural supply chain, processing operations or one of the many support functions that hold our operations together, our people all share a common set of values and a commitment to high quality food.

Keith Warner

Keith qualified from Edinburgh University in 1997 with 2 degrees, one in veterinary medicine and surgery, and one in veterinary pathology. He began working for The Minster Veterinary Practice in York, England, in June of that year. Originally, he was a mixed animal veterinary surgeon, dealing in all species of animal. Over time, he moved to 100% poultry work. Keith, along with a colleague, set up the Hereford branch of Minster Veterinary Practice (now PHS) in 2000, becoming partner in April 2003. Keith worked with all aspects of poultry medicine, including Broiler breeders, Broiler chickens, Broiler turkeys, Commercial egg laying chickens, ducks and game. He also worked at all levels of enterprise size, from back-yard pets to large multi-national integrations.

In September 2014, The Minster Veterinary Practice became part of Origin, and Keith became a director of that business, with responsibilities specifically in the intensive livestock areas of pig and poultry medicine, and the commercial aspects of the wider business. Keith left Origin in August 2017, taking a role as UK and Ireland Poultry Business Manager for Huvepharma, a fast-growing global pharmaceutical company. Keith was responsible for Coccidiostats, Cocci vaccines, probiotics and antibiotics in the poultry species.

In April 2019, Keith commenced a role at Avara Foods Ltd, across the turkey and chicken operation, and all generations, until the point of catch of commercial birds. The specific responsibilities cover Welfare, food safety, agriculture assurance and veterinary health, working with three nominated private poultry veterinary practices.

About Moy Park

Moy Park is one of the UK’s top 15 food companies, Northern Ireland’s largest private sector business and one of Europe’s leading poultry producers. Moy Park supplies branded and own label chicken products to leading retailers and foodservice providers throughout the UK, Ireland and Europe and is the industry leading manufacturer of organic, free-range and higher welfare chicken. Moy Park employs over 800 farmers, processes up to six million birds per week (approximately a third of the UK’s fresh poultry market), and has over 35 million chickens on the ground at any given time.

item.title: Session 4 - Survival and application

Session programme

+00:05 10 minute oral presentations
S2: Transcriptome dynamics in chemostat culture reveal how Campylobacter jejuni transports glutamine as a nitrogen source for optimal growth and survival

Jonathan Holmes (University of Leicester)

S5: Survival of Campylobacter jejuni on eggshells
Ingrid Hansson (Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences)
S8: Establishing CRISPR interference system in Campylobacter jejuni
Ruby Coates (University of Cambridge)
S9: Fluoroquinolone resistance is associated with aerobic survival and is found at high levels in Campylobacter strains isolated from supermarket chicken
Gillian Carney (University College Dublin)
S10: Differences in amino acids utilization between Campylobacter jejuni M1 and 11168H – HILIC-MS and Genome-Scale Metabolic Modelling analysis
Noemi Tejera (Quadram Institute Bioscience)
S1: Basic mechanisms of adhesion crucial for Campylobacter jejuni biofilms
Anja Klančnik (Biotechnical Faculty, University of Ljubljana)
S7: Recurring genotypes of Campylobacter jejuni involved in human infection in Luxembourg and associated to specific phenotypic traits
Nennig Morgane (National Health Laboratory, Luxembourg)

Timings for individual programme items are specified as an offset from when the session begins.

See Registration session for information on how to connect.

Session chairs

  • Lisa Williams (Hartpury University)
  • Evangelos Mourkas (University of Bath)

item.title: Session 3 - Trends in Campylobacter epidemiology and public health
item.content:encoded:
Zoom link: TBA

Discord link: https://discord.gg/X7RNaUbczg

Session times

  • Day 2 Thursday 9th September 2021. 14:00-17:00 (BST/UTC+1)

Session programme

Time Item
+00:00 Opening remarks from Session Chairs
+00:05 Talks: Methodology advancements to Campylobacter characteristics
T9: Twenty years of Campylobacter research using sequencing data and PubMLST: how far we have come!
Frances M Colles (University of Oxford)
+00:15 5 minute lightning talk
T10: A high-resolution investigation of multi-strain Campylobacter infection of European broiler flocks with parallel sequencing
Frances M Colles (University of Oxford)
T14: Genomic characterisation of Campylobacter species in rural Bangladesh
Nikkon Sarker (Child Health Research Foundation)
T5: Rapid detection of Campylobacter in chicken flocks
Ann-Katrin Llarena (Norwegian University of Life Sciences)
----
+00:35 Question and answer
+00:45 Talks: Pathways of transmission and Public Health
T2: Campylobacter diversity in chicken meat
Agata Dziegiel (Quadram Institute Bioscience)
T6: Needle in a haystack: Using a direct sequencing approach to characterise Campylobacter in human stool
Bilal Djeghout (Quadram Institute Bioscience)
T15: Modeling Campylobacter infection dynamics and estimating immune parameters from the MAL-ED study using Approximate Bayesian Computation
Nitya Singh (University of Florida)
T4: Campylobacter contamination of chicken livers at slaughter
Alicia Manzanares Pedrosa (CReSA-IRTA)
+01:25 Break
+01:40 5 minute lightning talks
T13: Risk factors for Campylobacter among pregnant women and their newborns in rural Bangladesh
Nafiz Ahsan (Child Health Research Foundation)
T7: Understanding the seasonality of Campylobacter infection in commercial broiler chickens
Daniel Phillips (Swansea University)
T3: Monitoring Antibiotic Resistance in Campylobacter jejuni from Italy in the last 10 years (2011-2021)
Agustin Conesa (European Food Safety Authority)
P9: Genomic surveillance of Campylobacter in Italian poultry
Francesca Marotta (Istituto Zooprofilattico Sperimentale dell’Abruzzo e del Molise G.Caporale)
+02:05 Question and answer
+02:15 Surveillance trends of Campylobacter - see below
+02:45 Q&A (Theme: what research is needed to push surveillance forward)
+03:00 Session summary and close (Session chairs)

Surveillance trends of Campylobacter

Surveillance trends of Campylobacter is a special segment with talks and discussion with delegates from public health agencies from around the world. Speakers will discuss a range of topics including; the trends they see through their surveillance systems, emerging issues, and research questions or limitations they face in tackling Campylobacter.

Speakers include:

  • Public Health England (UK) - Dr. Frieda Jorgensen
  • Public Health Agency of Canada & Canadian Integrated Program for Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance (Canada) - Dr Anne Deckert
  • Food Safety and Inspection Service (USA) - Peter Evans/Mustafa Simmons
  • National Institute of Infectious Diseases (Japan) - Dr. Koji Yahara

Timings for individual programme items are specified as an offset from when the session begins.

See Registration session for information on how to connect.

Session chairs

  • Nicol Janecko (Quadram Institute Bioscience)
  • Andrew Grant (University of Cambridge)

item.title: Registration still open!
item.description: Registration for this conference is without cost (free). To register and access all sessions, please complete the registration form: https://forms.gle/6ek3b6s6TRQHiyLw5
item.content:encoded:
Abstract submissions are now closed for CampyUK goes global 2021.

You can still register to attend using this link: https://forms.gle/6ek3b6s6TRQHiyLw5

The deadline for abstract submissions was 13th July 2021.

Abstract Submission Guidelines

Abstracts are limited to 3,000 characters. Submission should include an informative title, author list, affiliations, and abstract text.

The abstract should summarise the research in a concise and informative way, as it is the only information organisers will have when deciding what presentations will be accepted. Abstracts do not have to be structured in sections, however all abstracts should have a brief background statement summarising the basis for the work, and the aim of the work followed by methods, results and a concluding statement to bring the work into context within the research area.

You will also be able to add a brief biography about yourself (maximum 2,000 characters). You can just add links your profile on your organisation’s website if you like.
